medium: Kola nut, indigo, and watercolor on board
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund

makers.displaydate: born 1970, Kano, Nigeria; active Abuja and Kaduna, Nigeria and Princeton, NJ
makers.displaymaker: Marcia Kure, born 1970, Kano, Nigeria; active Abuja and Kaduna, Nigeria and Princeton, NJ

texts.textentryhtml: Marcia Kure, the artist, Princeton, New Jersey, consigned; to [Susan Inglett Gallery, New New York], sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.
texts.remarks: As per PL curatorial note. AP.

texts.textentryhtml: In the Amina Project, Kure takes Queen Amina of Zaria (1533–1610) as her protagonist in a series of abstracted figural portraits that imagine both the sixteenth-century Hausa queen, who ruled the city-state of Zaria in present-day northern Nigeria, and her royal attendants. Kure’s amorphous, headless figures shape-shift, the boundaries of their bodies dissolving into the mottled background. She achieves her variegated surfaces by expertly manipulating materials, including kola-nut juice and indigo—important commodities in the global trade routes that Queen Amina controlled.

displaymaker: Marcia Kure, born 1970, Kano, Nigeria; active Abuja and Kaduna, Nigeria and Princeton, NJ
caption: Marcia Kure (born 1970, Kano, Nigeria; active Abuja and Kaduna, Nigeria and Princeton, NJ), Dogariya / The Queen’s Guard, 2022. Kola nut, indigo, and watercolor on board; 61 × 45.7 cm, 66.5 × 51.3 × 4.1 cm (frame). Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund (2022-209)
